terms.name: contact affiliation
terms.value: University of Texas at Austin Molecular Biosciences

description: The field of proteomics has expanded recently with more sensitive techniques for the bulk measurement of peptides as well as single-molecule techniques. One limiting factor for these methods is the need for multiple chemical derivatizations and highly pure proteins free of contaminants. We show a solid-phase capture strategy suitable for the proteolysis, purification, and subsequent chemical modification of peptides. We use this resin on an HEK293T cell lysate and perform one-pot proteolysis, capture, and derivatization to generate a cellular proteome that identified over 8,000 proteins. We also show that this capture can be reversed in a traceless manner, such that it is amenable for single-molecule proteomics techniques. With this technique, we perform a fluorescent labeling and C-terminal differentiation on a peptide and subject it to fluorosequencing demonstrating that washing the resin is sufficient to remove excess dyes prior to single-molecule protein sequencing.

terms.name: Reference
terms.value: Howard CJ, Floyd BM, Bardo AM, Swaminathan J, Marcotte EM, Anslyn EV. Solid-Phase Peptide Capture and Release for Bulk and Single-Molecule Proteomics. ACS Chem Biol. 2020 15(6):1401-1407

title: Peptide N-terminal Bead Capture and Release
